On the Corporate Level, the executive responsibility to safely manage all hazardous waste operations rests with the President and CEO of Environmental Services and Solutions. The Director of Health and Safety has the authority to develop and require the implementation of corporate-wide safety and health programs to promote a safe, healthful work environment and promote regulatory compliance.

The Branch Health and Safety manager shall ensure that all elements of the CHSP are being implemented in compliance with all federal, state, and local regulations. The Branch General Manager is responsible for providing the necessary resources for meeting the requirements of the CHSP at the branch level and is responsible for the safety of their employees and the operations under their control. Operation Managers and Supervisors are responsible for the safety of their employees and operations under their control. They are to ensure that their employees are following the requirements set out in the program. Employees are responsible for working safely and following the requirements of the program. Employees are also responsible for reporting unsafe acts or conditions to their supervisors or managers.

Veolia is committed to protecting and enhancing the environment and to operating facilities in full
compliance with all applicable laws. Component number seven of Veolia's corporate Environmental Policy outlines Veolia's commitment to risk reduction:

Veolia will operate in a manner designed to minimize environmental, health, and safety hazards.

Veolia will minimize risk and protect employees and others in the vicinity of operations by employingsafe technologies and operating procedures and by being prepared for emergencies.

Veolia will adopt safe working practices, train employees on these practices, and insist that these safe work practices be followed.

As part of the facility's training program, employees are instructed in the nature and hazards of the chemicals with which they may come in contact. All employees are trained on the facility evacuation procedures, and evacuations drills are conducted regularly.

Five-Year Accident History

There have been no accidents at the facility in the last five years involving the release of the
chemicals covered by this RMP.

Emergency Response Program

In addition to the Emergency Action Plan, the Henderson Facility administers programs regarding mechanical integrity, including preventive maintenance, management of change, process hazard analysis and all other elements covered within the PSM standard (29 CFR 1910.119).  All equipment at the facility is designed by qualified engineers and contractors.  Inspections of equipment, materials, and processes are performed to identify and correct deficiencies.

As a result of the VES Process Safety Management (PSM) assessment, staff operation areas have been relocated to secure locations away from waste storage areas (including the staff shower room and solvent distillation control room), lower explosive limit (LEL) monitoring equipment has been installed in waste storage areas (e.g., at tank batteries), and foam fire suppression systems are installed at all storage/handling locations (e.g., foam cannons, overhead deluge systems). 


Veolia's operation maintains an Emergency Action Plan that describes the actions to be taken by employ

that could cause environmental harm or pose potential health or safety hazards.

Veolia will mandate that employees report any condition that creates a danger to the environment orposes health or safety hazards and will provide confidential means for them to do so.

Veolia's approach to release prevention and risk reduction is based on a specific hierarchy of controls, namely elimination, substitution, engineering, administrative controls, and finally PPE. Because it is Veolia's business to receive the chemicals as wastes for safe management, elimination and substitution are not applicable.

To minimize the risk of an accidental release using engineering controls, Veolia designed the process to utilize top loading with a stinger to fill the railcars, which reduce the risk posed by a release from the bottom valve of the railcar. Secondary containment is in place for the tank truck, pump, hoses, and under the railcar bottom valve. The buildup of static electricity is prevented by using conductive hoses and the electrical bonding of tank trucks, pumps, and railcars. To minimize vapor releases, vapors are balanced between the tanker and railcar. High-level alarms are present on the railcars (activate at 90% full), to prevent overfilling.

Administrative controls implemented to minimize the risk of an accidental release include:

Standard Operating Procedures with job safety analysis for each part of the process.

Inspection programs covering equipment, materials, and processes to identify and correct deficiencies.

Hazardous Materials Management Plan that includes fire prevention and control requirements.

Comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures. Refresher training is provided at least every three years and more frequently as needed.

Facility Description and Regulated Substances Handled

Veolia Environmental Services (Veolia) operates a fully permitted hazardous waste treatment, storage, and disposal facility (TSDF) and fuels blending facility in Henderson, Colorado.  The facility receives waste materials, primarily organic solvent wastes, from various manufacturers.  Once on-site, the waste materials are separated into various waste and product categories depending on how the material will be processed.  Certain types of wastes are treated and processed to recover products that may be reused/recycled by industrial customers.  Other wastes are prepared for shipment to other Veolia or non-Veolia facilities for additional treatment or disposal.

There will be one process at the facility that can store a regulated chemical (piperidine) in quantity sufficient to require the preparation and implementation of this Risk Management Plan (RMP). The process will be performed on an event basis for one year, and Veolia will terminate this RMP plan at the end of the year.

The RMP-regulated process involves the transloading of  N, N-Dimethylformamide (DMF) containing up to 20% piperidine from tank trucks delivered to the facility into railcars, with the heaviest car weighing 206,500 lbs. Once complete, Veolia will ship railcars off-site.


At most, 16,000 pounds of piperidine may be present on-site in the DMF transloading process. There are no other processes at the facility currently storing, handling, using, or processing chemicals in quantities sufficient to require their inclusion in this RMP.
